title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Kantana loves chocolate. Every Saturday she goes to the candy store and buys 2 chocolates for herself and 1 for her sister. This last Saturday she picked up an additional 10 chocolates as a birthday gift for her friend Charlie. How many chocolates did Kantana end up buying for the month?

Since there are 4 Saturdays in a month, Kantana bought 4 x (2 + 1) = <<4*(2+1)=12>>12 chocolates for herself and her sister.
Therefore, Kantana bought 12 + 10 = <<12+10=22>>22 chocolates for the month. Answer: \boxed{22}.


Question: Kantana loves chocolate. Every Saturday she goes to the candy store and buys 2 chocolates for herself and 1 for her sister. This last Saturday she picked up an additional 10 chocolates as a birthday gift for her friend Charlie. How many chocolates did Kantana end up buying for the month?

There are 4 Saturdays in a month because 52 / 12 = <<52/12=4>>4
Kantana buys 2 + 1 = <<2+1=3>>3 chocolates every Saturday.
Kantana buys 12 chocolates for herself and her sister because 3 x 4 = <<3*4=12>>12
She bought an extra 10 for Charlie because 12 + 10 = <<12+10=22>>22
Kantana bought 22 chocolates this month. Answer: \boxed{22}.


Question: Kantana loves chocolate. Every Saturday she goes to the candy store and buys 2 chocolates for herself and 1 for her sister. This last Saturday she picked up an additional 10 chocolates as a birthday gift for her friend Charlie. How many chocolates did Kantana end up buying for the month?

There are typically 4 Saturdays in a month (1 for each week).
For each Saturday, Kantana buys 2 chocolates for herself and 1 for her sister, so she buys 2 + 1 = <<2+1=3>>3 chocolates per Saturday.
Over 4 Saturdays, Kantana buys a total of 4 * 3 = <<4*3=12>>12 chocolates for herself and her sister.
Kantana also bought an additional 10 chocolates for her friend, so she bought a total of 12 + 10 = <<12+10=22>>22 chocolates for the month. Answer: \boxed{22}.


Question: Kantana loves chocolate. Every Saturday she goes to the candy store and buys 2 chocolates for herself and 1 for her sister. This last Saturday she picked up an additional 10 chocolates as a birthday gift for her friend Charlie. How many chocolates did Kantana end up buying for the month?

There are typically 4 Saturdays in a month. 

For each Saturday, Kantana buys 2 chocolates for herself and 1 for her sister, for a total of 2+1 = <<2+1=3>>3 chocolates per Saturday.
For 4 Saturdays, Kantana would buy 3 chocolates for each Saturday, a total of 3*4 = <<3*4=12>>12 chocolates for the month for herself and her sister.

On this last Saturday, Kantana purchased an additional 10 chocolates for her friend Charlie.

For the entire month, Kantana ended up buying 12+10 = <<12+10=22>>22 chocolates. Answer: \boxed{22}.


Question: Matilda had 20 chocolate bars and shared them evenly amongst herself and her 4 sisters. When her father got home from work, he was upset that they did not put aside any chocolates for him. They felt bad, so they each gave up half of their chocolate bars for their father. Their father then gave 3 chocolate bars to their mother and ate 2. How many chocolate bars did Matilda's father have left?

Matilda and her sisters each received 20 / 5 = <<20/5=4>>4 chocolate bars.
They gave half of their chocolate bars away for their father, so each gave up 4 / 2 = <<4/2=2>>2 chocolate bars.
Since there were 5 of them, Matilda's father received 2 x 5 = <<2*5=10>>10 chocolate bars.
He gave 3 chocolate bars to their mom and ate 2, so he had 10 - 3 - 2 = <<10-3-2=5>>5 chocolate bars left. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: Nida has 50 chocolates in which some are in 3 filled boxes and 5 pieces are not in a box. Her friend brought 25 pieces of chocolates. If all chocolates must be placed in a box, how many more boxes do they need?
text:
Nida currently has 50 chocolates, with 3 filled boxes and 5 pieces not in a box. This means there are 50 - 3*10 - 5 = <<50-3*10-5=17>>17 chocolates that need to be placed in boxes.

Since each box can hold 10 chocolates, they will need 17 / 10 = <<17/10=1.7>>1.7 more boxes.

Since the number of boxes needed must be a whole number, they will need 2 more boxes.

Answer: \boxed{2}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: There are 24 students in the class. One-third had their school portraits taken before lunch. After lunch, but before gym class, 10 additional students had their portraits taken. After gym class, how many students have not yet had their picture taken?

One-third of 24 students is 24 / 3 = <<24/3=8>>8 students.
After lunch, 8 + 10 students = <<8+10=18>>18 students had their picture taken.
Thus, 24 students - 18 students = <<24-18=6>>6 students have not yet had their picture taken. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: There are 24 students in the class. One-third had their school portraits taken before lunch. After lunch, but before gym class, 10 additional students had their portraits taken. After gym class, how many students have not yet had their picture taken?

Before lunch, 24/3 = <<24/3=8>>8 students had their picture taken.
Before gym class, 8+10 = <<8+10=18>>18 students had their picture taken.
Thus, 24 - 18 = <<24-18=6>>6 students have not yet had their picture taken. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: There are 24 students in the class. One-third had their school portraits taken before lunch. After lunch, but before gym class, 10 additional students had their portraits taken. After gym class, how many students have not yet had their picture taken?

One-third of 24 students is (1/3)*24 = <<(1/3)*24=8>>8 students.
Before gym class, there were already 8+10 = <<8+10=18>>18 students who had their school portraits taken.
Out of the 24 students, 24-18 = <<24-18=6>>6 students have not yet had their picture taken. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: There are 24 students in the class. One-third had their school portraits taken before lunch. After lunch, but before gym class, 10 additional students had their portraits taken. After gym class, how many students have not yet had their picture taken?

One-third of the 24 students had their picture taken before lunch, so there are 24/3 = <<24/3=8>>8 students who had their picture taken before lunch.
10 more students had their picture taken after lunch, so there are a total of 8 + 10 = <<8+10=18>>18 students who had their picture taken before or after lunch.
Thus, there are 24 - 18 = <<24-18=6>>6 students who have not had their picture taken. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: The Period 1 gym class has 5 fewer than twice as many students as in the Period 2 gym class. There are 11 students in the Period 1 gym class. How many are in the Period 2 gym class?

Twice the number of students in the Period 2 gym class is 11 + 5 = <<11+5=16>>16.
So, the Period 2 gym class has 16/2 = <<16/2=8>>8 students. Answer: \boxed{8}.


Question: There are 24 students in the class. One-third had their school portraits taken before lunch. After lunch, but before gym class, 10 additional students had their portraits taken. After gym class, how many students have not yet had their picture taken?
text:
One-third of the 24 students had their picture taken before lunch, which is 24/3 = <<24/3=8>>8 students.
After lunch, 10 additional students had their picture taken, so the total number of students who had their picture taken is 8 + 10 = <<8+10=18>>18.
Therefore, the number of students who have not yet had their picture taken is 24 - 18 = <<24-18=6>>6. Answer: \boxed{6}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A captain steers his ship 100 miles north on the first day of their journey. On the second day, he sails to the east three times as far as the distance as he covered on the first day. On the third day, the ship travels further east for 110 more miles than the distance it covered on the second day. What is the total distance the ship has traveled in the three days?

On the second day, the captain steers his ship 3 * 100 = <<3*100=300>>300 miles east.
The distance covered by the ship in the third day is 300 + 110 = <<300+110=410>>410 miles east.
In the three days, the ship covers 100 + 300 + 410 = <<100+300+410=810>>810 miles. Answer: \boxed{810}.


Question: A captain steers his ship 100 miles north on the first day of their journey. On the second day, he sails to the east three times as far as the distance as he covered on the first day. On the third day, the ship travels further east for 110 more miles than the distance it covered on the second day. What is the total distance the ship has traveled in the three days?

On the second day, the captain traveled 100 miles * 3 = <<100*3=300>>300 miles east.
On the third day, the captain traveled 300 miles + 110 miles = <<300+110=410>>410 miles east.
In the three days, the ship traveled a total of 100 miles + 300 miles + 410 miles = <<100+300+410=810>>810 miles. Answer: \boxed{810}.

On the third day, the ship sails 300 miles + 110 miles = <<300+110=410>>410 miles to the east.
In the three days, the ship has traveled a total of 100 miles + 300 miles + 410 miles = <<100+300+410=810>>810 miles. Answer: \boxed{810}.

On the third day, the ship travels further east for 110 more miles than the distance it covered on the second day. What is the total distance the ship has traveled in the three days?

On the second day, the ship sails 3 * 100 miles = <<3*100=300>>300 miles to the east.
The total distance covered in the first two days is 300 miles + 100 miles = <<300+100=400>>400 miles.
On the third day, the ship travels 300 miles + 110 miles = <<300+110=410>>410 miles to the east.
The total distance the ship has traveled in the three days is 410 miles + 400 miles = <<410+400=810>>810 miles. Answer: \boxed{810}.


Question: A captain steers his ship 100 miles north on the first day of their journey. On the second day, he sails to the east three times as far as the distance as he covered on the first day. On the third day, the ship travels further east for 110 more miles than the distance it covered on the second day. What is the total distance the ship has traveled in the three days?

On the second day, the captain sails 3 * 100 miles = <<3*100=300>>300 miles to the east.

The total distance the ship has traveled in the three days is 300 miles + 410 miles + 100 miles = <<300+410+100=810>>810 miles. Answer: \boxed{810}.


Question: A captain steers his ship 100 miles north on the first day of their journey. On the second day, he sails to the east three times as far as the distance as he covered on the first day. On the third day, the ship travels further east for 110 more miles than the distance it covered on the second day. What is the total distance the ship has traveled in the three days?
text:
On the second day, the captain sails 3 * 100 miles = <<3*100=300>>300 miles to the east.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Gerald thought it would be funny to trick his coworker, who's allergic to peanuts, into eating a peanut butter cookie. When his coworker goes into anaphylactic shock and is taken to the hospital, Gerald is arrested. The judge sentences Gerald to 3 months for assault and 2 years for poisoning, then extends his sentence by 1/3 since this is Gerald's third offense. How many months does Gerald spend in jail?

Gerald's initial sentence is 3 months for assault and 2 years (24 months) for poisoning. 

The total sentence before the extension is 3 + 24 = <<3+24=27>>27 months.

Since this is Gerald's third offense, his sentence is extended by 1/3, which is (1/3) * 27 = <<(1/3)*27=9>>9 months.

Therefore, Gerald spends a total of 27 + 9 = <<27+9=36>>36 months in jail. Answer: \boxed{36}.


Question: Lou Senior took 3 cookies out of the cookie jar and ate them.  Since he didn't get caught by his wife, he went back the next day and took another 3 cookies out of the jar.  But after eating just one of the cookies, he felt guilty about it and put the other two cookies back.  His son, Louie Junior saw that his Dad was eating cookies.  So, Louie Junior took seven cookies out of the jar and hid them in his bedroom for later.  The next morning, Debra, Lou's wife looked into the cookie jar and reacted by accusing her husband of eating half of the cookies out of the cookie jar.  How many cookies remained in the jar?

Lou Senior initially took 3 cookies out of the jar. After eating one and putting the other two back, he took a total of 4 cookies out of the jar. Louie Junior then took 7 cookies out of the jar and hid them in his bedroom. 
Therefore, the total number of cookies taken out of the jar is 4 + 7 = 11.
If Debra accused Lou Senior of eating half of the cookies, it means that there were originally 11 x 2 = <<11*2=22>>22 cookies in the jar. 
Since 11 cookies were taken out, there were 22 - 11 = <<22-11=11>>11 cookies remaining in the jar. Answer: \boxed{11}.


Question: At the polar bear club, Jerry and his three friends, Elaine, George, and Kramer, took turns jumping into a swimming pool filled with freezing-cold water.  Jerry was in the pool for 3 minutes before becoming too cold to remain in the cold water.  Elaine stayed in the pool for twice as long as Jerry.  George could only stay in the pool for one-third as long as Elaine.  And Kramer, who accidentally locked himself in the bathroom, could not find the pool.  What is the combined total of minutes that Jerry and his friends were in the cold water?

Elaine stayed in the pool for 2 * 3 = <<2*3=6>>6 minutes.
George stayed in the pool for 1/3 * 6 = <<1/3*6=2>>2 minutes.
Jerry, Elaine, and George spent a total of 3 + 6 + 2 = <<3+6+2=11>>11 minutes in the pool. Answer: \boxed{11}.


Question: Mrs. Carlton gives out penalty points whenever her students misbehave. They get 5 points for interrupting, 10 points for insulting their classmates, and 25 points for throwing things. If they get 100 points, they have to go to the office. Jerry already interrupted twice and insulted his classmates 4 times. How many times can he throw things before he gets sent to the office?

Jerry has already interrupted twice, so he has 2 * 5 = <<2*5=10>>10 points.
Jerry has insulted his peers 4 times, so he has 4 * 10 = <<4*10=40>>40 points.
Jerry has 10 + 40 = <<10+40=50>>50 points from interrupting and insulting.
Jerry can throw 100 - 50 = <<100-50=50>>50 points before going to the office.
Jerry can throw things 50 / 25 = <<50/25=2>>2 times. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: At the polar bear club, Jerry and his three friends, Elaine, George, and Kramer, took turns jumping into a swimming pool filled with freezing-cold water.  Jerry was in the pool for 3 minutes before becoming too cold to remain in the cold water.  Elaine stayed in the pool for twice as long as Jerry.  George could only stay in the pool for one-third as long as Elaine.  And Kramer, who accidentally locked himself in the bathroom, could not find the pool.  What is the combined total of minutes that Jerry and his friends were in the cold water?

Jerry was in the pool for 3 minutes before becoming too cold.
Elaine stayed in the pool for twice as long as Jerry, so Elaine stayed in the pool for 3 x 2 = <<3*2=6>>6 minutes.
George could only stay in the pool for one-third as long as Elaine, so George stayed in the pool for 6 / 3 = <<6/3=2>>2 minutes.
Kramer, who accidentally locked himself in the bathroom, could not find the pool, so Kramer spent 0 minutes in the pool.
The combined total of minutes that Jerry and his friends were in the cold water is 3 + 6 + 2 + 0 = <<3+6+2+0=11>>11 minutes. Answer: \boxed{11}.


Question: Gerald thought it would be funny to trick his coworker, who's allergic to peanuts, into eating a peanut butter cookie. When his coworker goes into anaphylactic shock and is taken to the hospital, Gerald is arrested. The judge sentences Gerald to 3 months for assault and 2 years for poisoning, then extends his sentence by 1/3 since this is Gerald's third offense. How many months does Gerald spend in jail?
text:
Gerald's initial sentence is 3 months for assault and 2 years (24 months) for poisoning. 

The total sentence before the extension is 3 + 24 = 27 months.

Since this is Gerald's third offense, his sentence is extended by 1/3, which is (1/3) * 27 = 9 months.

Therefore, Gerald spends a total of 27 + 9 = 36 months in jail. Answer: \boxed{36}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Five food companies sponsored a local food bank. Foster Farms donated 45 dressed chickens; American Summits donated twice the number of bottled water than the number of dressed chicken donated by Foster Farms; Hormel donated three times the number of dressed chickens that Foster Farms donated; Boudin Butchers donated one-third of the number of dressed chickens that Hormel donated; Del Monte Foods donated 30 fewer bottles of water than American Summits. How many food items did the companies donate in total?

Foster Farms donated 45 dressed chickens.
American Summits donated twice the number of dressed chickens, so they donated 2 * 45 dressed chickens = <<2*45=90>>90 dressed chickens.
Hormel donated three times the number of dressed chickens, so they donated 3 * 45 dressed chickens = <<3*45=135>>135 dressed chickens.
Boudin Butchers donated one-third the number of dressed chickens, so they donated 1/3 * 135 dressed chickens = <<1/3*135=45>>45 dressed chickens.
Del Monte Foods donated 30 fewer bottles of water than American Summits, so they donated 90 - 30 = <<90-30=60>>60 bottles of water.
The total number of dressed chickens donated is 45 + 90 + 135 + 45 = <<45+90+135+45=315>>315 dressed chickens.
The total number of items donated is 315 + 60 = <<315+60=375>>375 items. Answer: \boxed{375}.


Question: Five food companies sponsored a local food bank. Foster Farms donated 45 dressed chickens; American Summits donated twice the number of bottled water than the number of dressed chicken donated by Foster Farms; Hormel donated three times the number of dressed chickens that Foster Farms donated; Boudin Butchers donated one-third of the number of dressed chickens that Hormel donated; Del Monte Foods donated 30 fewer bottles of water than American Summits. How many food items did the companies donate in total?

Foster Farms donated 45 dressed chickens.
American Summits donated twice the number of dressed chickens donated by Foster Farms, so they donated 2*45 = <<2*45=90>>90 bottles of water.
Hormel donated three times the number of dressed chickens donated by Foster Farms, so they donated 3*45 = <<3*45=135>>135 dressed chickens.
Boudin Butchers donated one-third of the number of dressed chickens donated by Hormel, so they donated 1/3*135 = <<1/3*135=45>>45 dressed chickens.
Del Monte Foods donated 30 fewer bottles of water than American Summits, so they donated 90-30 = <<90-30=60>>60 bottles of water.
The total number of dressed chickens donated is 45+135+45 = <<45+135+45=225>>225 dressed chickens.
The total number of bottled water donated is 90+60 = <<90+60=150>>150 bottles of water.
The five food companies donated a total of 225+150 = <<225+150=375>>375 food items. Answer: \boxed{375}.


Question: Five food companies sponsored a local food bank. Foster Farms donated 45 dressed chickens; American Summits donated twice the number of bottled water than the number of dressed chicken donated by Foster Farms; Hormel donated three times the number of dressed chickens that Foster Farms donated; Boudin Butchers donated one-third of the number of dressed chickens that Hormel donated; Del Monte Foods donated 30 fewer bottles of water than American Summits. American Summits donated 45 x 2 = <<45*2=90>>90 bottles of water.

Boudin Butchers donated 135/3 = <<135/3=45>>45 dressed chickens.
Del Monte Foods donated 90 - 30 = <<90-30=60>>60 bottles of water.
Therefore, a total of 45 dressed chickens + 90 bottles of water + 135 dressed chickens + 45 dressed chickens + 60 bottles of water = <<45+90+135+45+60=375>>375 food items were donated. Answer: \boxed{375}.

Question: Five food companies sponsored a local food bank. Foster Farms donated 45 dressed chickens; American Summits donated twice the number of bottled water than the number of dressed chicken donated by Foster Farms; Hormel donated three times the number of dressed chickens that Foster Farms donated; Boudin Butchers donated one-third of the number of dressed chickens that Hormel donated; Del Monte Foods donated 30 fewer bottles of water than American Summits. title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Tom's cat needs an expensive surgery.  He has had pet insurance for 24 months that cost $20 per month.  The procedure cost $5000 but the insurance covers all but 20% of this.  How much money did he save by having insurance?

He paid for insurance for 24 months at a cost of $20 per month so he paid 24*20 = $<<24*20=480>>480
The surgery cost $5000 and insurance covered 80% of it so that's .80*5000 = $<<5000*.80=4000>>4000 for insurance to cover
The surgery cost $5000, insurance covered $4000 of it so he had to pay 5000-4000 = $<<5000-4000=1000>>1000 out of pocket
He paid $480 for insurance over 2 years and the surgery cost $1000 so all total he paid 480+1000 = $<<480+1000=1480>>1,480
Without insurance the surgery would have cost $5000, with insurance it cost him 1480 so he saved 5000-1480 = $<<5000-1480=3520>>3,520. Answer: \boxed{3520}.


Question: Tom broke his leg and needed to go to the doctor.  The visit cost $300 and the cast cost $200.  If insurance covered 60% how much was Tom's out-of-pocket cost?

The insurance covered 300+200=$<<300+200=500>>500 to start
That means Tom had to pay 500*.4=$<<500*.4=200>>200 out of pocket. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Tim's cat bit him.  He decided to get himself and the cat checked out.  His doctor's visits $300 and insurance covered 75%.  His cat's visit cost $120 and his pet insurance covered $60.  How much did he pay?

Insurance covered 300*.75=$<<300*.75=225>>225 for his doctor's visit
So he paid 300-225=$<<300-225=75>>75 for that visit
Insurance covered 120-60=$<<120-60=60>>60 for the cat visit
So he paid 120-60=$<<120-60=60>>60 for it
So he paid 75+60=$<<75+60=135>>135. Answer: \boxed{135}.


Question: Tim's cat bit him.  He decided to get himself and the cat checked out.  His doctor's visits $300 and insurance covered 75%.  His cat's visit cost $120 and his pet insurance covered $60.  How much did he pay?

The doctor's visit cost 300*.25=$<<300*.25=75>>75
The cat's visit cost 120-60=$<<120-60=60>>60
So together he had to pay 75+60=$<<75+60=135>>135. Answer: \boxed{135}.


Question: Tim's cat bit him.  He decided to get himself and the cat checked out.  His doctor's visits $300 and insurance covered 75%.  His cat's visit cost $120 and his pet insurance covered $60.  How much did he pay?

His doctors visit cost $300 * .25 = $<<300*.25=75>>75
His cat's visits cost $120 - $60 = $<<120-60=60>>60
So he pays $75 + $60 = $<<75+60=135>>135. Answer: \boxed{135}.


Question: Tom's cat needs an expensive surgery.  He has had pet insurance for 24 months that cost $20 per month.  The procedure cost $5000 but the insurance covers all but 20% of this.  How much money did he save by having insurance?
text:
He paid for insurance for 24 months at a cost of $20 per month so he paid 24*20 = $480. 
The surgery cost $5000 and insurance covered 80% of it so that's .80*5000 = $4000 for insurance to cover. 
The surgery cost $5000, insurance covered $4000 of it so he had to pay 5000-4000 = $1000 out of pocket. 
He paid $480 for insurance over 2 years and the surgery cost $1000 so all total he paid 480+1000 = $1480. 
Without insurance the surgery would have cost $5000, with insurance it cost him 1480 so he saved 5000-1480 = $3520. Answer: \boxed{3520}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Miriam is trying to exercise more and figures if she counts her exercises it will be encouraging to see her numbers go up. On Monday she does 5 push-ups. On Tuesday she does 7 push-ups. On Wednesday she does twice as many push-ups as the day before. On Thursday she does half the number of total pushups she already did that week. Finally, on Friday she does as many pushups as the total number she did over the previous four days. How many pushups does Miriam do on Friday?

On Monday and Tuesday, Miriam does a total of 5 + 7 = <<5+7=12>>12 push-ups.
On Wednesday she does 7 * 2 = <<7*2=14>>14 push-ups.
The total number of push-ups she does by Wednesday is 12 + 14 = <<12+14=26>>26 push-ups.
On Thursday she does 26 / 2 = <<26/2=13>>13 push-ups.
By the end of Thursday, Miriam has done 26 + 13 = <<26+13=39>>39 push-ups.
Thus, she does 39 push-ups on Friday. Answer: \boxed{39}.


Question: Miriam is trying to exercise more and figures if she counts her exercises it will be encouraging to see her numbers go up. On Monday she does 5 push-ups. On Tuesday she does 7 push-ups. On Wednesday she does twice as many push-ups as the day before. On Thursday she does half the number of total pushups she already did that week. Finally, on Friday she does as many pushups as the total number she did over the previous four days. How many pushups does Miriam do on Friday?

On Monday and Tuesday, Miriam does a total of 5 + 7 = <<5+7=12>>12 push-ups.
On Wednesday, she does twice the number of push-ups as the day before, for a total of 7 * 2 = <<7*2=14>>14 push-ups.
On Thursday she does half the number of push-ups she had done so far that week, which is (5 + 7 + 14) / 2 = <<(5+7+14)/2=13>>13 push-ups.
Finally, on Friday, she does as many push-ups as the total number she did over the previous four days, or 5 + 7 + 14 + 13 = <<5+7+14+13=39>>39 push-ups. Answer: \boxed{39}.


Question: Miriam is trying to exercise more and figures if she counts her exercises it will be encouraging to see her numbers go up. On Monday she does 5 push-ups. On Tuesday she does 7 push-ups. On Wednesday she does twice as many push-ups as the day before. On Thursday she does half the number of total pushups she already did that week. Finally, on Friday she does as many pushups as the total number she did over the previous four days. How many pushups does Miriam do on Friday?

On Monday and Tuesday, Miriam does 5 + 7 = <<5+7=12>>12 push-ups.
On Wednesday she does twice as many push-ups as the day before, so she does 2 * 7 = <<2*7=14>>14 push-ups.
By this point, she has done a total of 12 + 14 = <<12+14=26>>26 push-ups.
On Thursday she does half the number of total push-ups she already did that week, so she does 26 / 2 = <<26/2=13>>13 push-ups.
Finally, on Friday she does as many push-ups as the total number she did over the previous four days, resulting in her doing 5 + 7 + 14 + 13 = <<5+7+14+13=39>>39 push-ups in total on Friday. Answer: \boxed{39}.


Question: Miriam spent 30 minutes doing laundry, 15 minutes cleaning the bathroom, a certain amount of time cleaning her room, and 40 minutes doing homework. If she spent a total of two hours on these tasks, how long, in minutes, did she spend cleaning her room?

Two hours is equal to 2 * 60 = <<2*60=120>>120 minutes.
Thus, Miriam spent a total of 120 - 30 - 15 - 40 = <<120-30-15-40=35>>35 minutes cleaning her room. Answer: \boxed{35}.


Question: Miriam spent 30 minutes doing laundry, 15 minutes cleaning the bathroom, a certain amount of time cleaning her room, and 40 minutes doing homework. If she spent a total of two hours on these tasks, how long, in minutes, did she spend cleaning her room?

In total, Miriam spent 30+15+40 = <<30+15+40=85>>85 minutes on the laundry, bathroom cleaning, and homework.
Miriam spent 2*60 = <<2*60=120>>120 minutes on all of the tasks together.
Miriam spent 120-85 = <<120-85=35>>35 minutes on cleaning her room. Answer: \boxed{35}.


Question: Miriam is trying to exercise more and figures if she counts her exercises it will be encouraging to see her numbers go up. On Monday she does 5 push-ups. On Tuesday she does 7 push-ups. On Wednesday she does twice as many push-ups as the day before. On Thursday she does half the number of total pushups she already did that week. Finally, on Friday she does as many pushups as the total number she did over the previous four days. How many pushups does Miriam do on Friday?
text:
On Monday, Miriam does 5 push-ups.
On Tuesday, Miriam does 7 push-ups.
On Wednesday, Miriam does twice as many push-ups as the day before. Therefore, she does 7 * 2 = 14 push-ups on Wednesday.
By Wednesday, she has done a total of 5 + 7 + 14 = 26 push-ups.
On Thursday, Miriam does half the number of total push-ups she already did that week. Thus, she does 26 / 2 = 13 push-ups on Thursday.
Finally, on Friday, she does as many push-ups as the total number she did over the previous four days, which is 5 + 7 + 14 + 13 = 39 push-ups. Answer: \boxed{39}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Harry needs to buy 5 spellbooks that each cost 5 gold, three potion kits that each cost 20 silver, and one owl that costs 28 gold. There are 9 silver to a gold. How much will Harry pay total, in silvers?

Harry will pay 5 * 5 = <<5*5=25>>25 gold for spellbooks.
Harry will pay 3 * 20 = <<3*20=60>>60 silver for the potion kits.
Combining both in gold, Harry will pay 25 + 28 = <<25+28=53>>53 gold
In silver, this is equal to 53 * 9 = <<53*9=477>>477 silver.
Combining potion kit cost, spellbook cost, and owl cost, Harry will pay 477 + 60 = <<477+60=537>>537 silver total. Answer: \boxed{537}.


Question: Harry has 50 books in his library. His sister Flora has twice as many books and their cousin Gary has half the books Harry has. How many books do the three of them own together?

Flora has 50 x 2 = <<50*2=100>>100 books.
Gary has 50/2 = <<50/2=25>>25 books.
Therefore, they have a total of 50 + 100 + 25 = <<50+100+25=175>>175 books. Answer: \boxed{175}.


Question: Harry has 50 books in his library. His sister Flora has twice as many books and their cousin Gary has half the books Harry has. How many books do the three of them own together?

Flora has 50 x 2 = <<50*2=100>>100 books.
Gary has 50/2 = <<50/2=25>>25 books.
So, together, they have 50 + 100 + 25 = <<50+100+25=175>>175 books. Answer: \boxed{175}.


Question: Harry is a professional dog-walker.  He is paid to go on long walks with dogs while their families are away from home.  On Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, Harry walks 7 dogs.  On Tuesday, he walks 12 dogs.  And on Thursday he walks 9 dogs.  He is paid $5 for each dog that he walks.  How many dollars does Harry earn in a week?

On Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, Harry walks 7 * 3 = <<7*3=21>>21 dogs.
So for those days, he earns 21 * 5 = <<21*5=105>>105 dollars.
He also earns 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 dollars on Tuesday.
And he earns 9 * 5 = <<9*5=45>>45 dollars on Thursday.
Therefore, Harry earns a total of 105 + 60 + 45 = <<105+60+45=210>>210 dollars in a week. Answer: \boxed{210}.


Question: Harry has 50 books in his library. His sister Flora has twice as many books and their cousin Gary has half the books Harry has. How many books do the three of them own together?

Flora has 50 x 2 = <<50*2=100>>100 books.
Gary has 50/2 = <<50/2=25>>25 books.
So, they have a total of 50 + 100 + 25 = <<50+100+25=175>>175 books. Answer: \boxed{175}.


Question: Harry needs to buy 5 spellbooks that each cost 5 gold, three potion kits that each cost 20 silver, and one owl that costs 28 gold. There are 9 silver to a gold. How much will Harry pay total, in silvers?
text:
Harry will pay 5 * 5 = <<5*5=25>>25 gold for spellbooks.
Harry will pay 3 * 20 = <<3*20=60>>60 silver for the potion kits.
Combining both in gold, Harry will pay 25 + 28 = <<25+28=53>>53 gold.
In silver, this is equal to 53 * 9 = <<53*9=477>>477 silver.
Combining potion kit cost, spellbook cost, and owl cost, Harry will pay 477 + 60 = <<477+60=537>>537 silver total. Answer: \boxed{537}.
